name: Ghidra
description: NSA's open-source reverse engineering suite with decompiler, p-code IR, and headless automation.
long_description: Ghidra is a modular reverse engineering framework supporting x86/x64, ARM, MIPS, RISC-V, and more. It provides disassembly, decompilation to a p-code IR, data-flow analysis, scripting in Java/Python, and headless batch pipelines for large-scale binary analysis.

tactics.name: headless_analysis
tactics.description: Run scripts and analyzers without the GUI.
tactics.when_to_use: Batch processing, CI pipelines, or large firmware sweeps.

tactics.name: decompiler_pcode
tactics.description: Inspect p-code to reason about compiler optimizations and control flow.
tactics.syntax: Use Decompiler â†’ P-code window or getPcode() in scripts
tactics.when_to_use: When verifying low-level semantics or validating calling conventions.

tactics.name: sleigh_override
tactics.description: Patch or extend instruction semantics with Sleigh.
tactics.syntax: Edit *.sla and re-run processor module build
tactics.when_to_use: To model custom opcodes or fix lifter semantics for verification.
examples: Modify ARM.sinc to add missing decode rule, rebuild, and re-run analysis

error_patterns.meaning: Selected binary architecture is not recognized.
fixes: Install or write a Sleigh processor module

performance.typical_runtime: seconds to minutes depending on analyzers
performance.scalability: Headless mode supports large firmware; analysis time grows with decompiler settings
performance.memory_usage: Medium to high; configure JVM heap for >1GB binaries

disadvantages: Decompiler accuracy varies by compiler/optimization level
